messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Learning-Based Algorithms for Graph Searching Problems

Paper Abstract: Abstract We consider the problem of graph searching with prediction recently introduced by Banerjee et al. (2023). In this problem, an agent, starting at some vertex rùëür has to traverse a (potentially unknown) graph Gùê∫G to find a hidden goal node gùëîg while minimizing the total distance travelled. We study a setting in which at any node vùë£v, the agent receives a noisy estimate of the distance from vùë£v to gùëîg. We design algorithms for this search task on unknown graphs. We establish the first formal guarantees on unknown weighted graphs and provide lower bounds showing that the algorithms we propose have optimal or nearly-optimal dependence on the prediction error. Further, we perform numerical experiments demonstrating that in addition to being robust to adversarial error, our algorithms perform well in typical instances in which the error is stochastic. Finally, we provide alternative simpler performance bounds on the algorithms of Banerjee et al. (2023) for the case of searching on a known graph, and establish new lower bounds for this setting.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Optimal Online Bipartite Matching with Degree Information",
        "The theory of search games and rendezvous, volume 55",
        "Customizing ml predictions for online algorithms",
        "Online computation with untrusted advice",
        "Online metric algorithms with untrusted predictions",
        "The primal-dual method for learning augmented algorithms",
        "Graph searching with predictions",
        "On-line searching and navigation",
        "Treasure hunt in graph using pebbles",
        "Almost-optimal deterministic treasure hunt in arbitrary graphs",
        "Triangle and four cycle counting with predictions in graph streams",
        "Composable sketches for functions of frequencies: Beyond the worst case",
        "Generalized best-first search strategies and the optimality of A*",
        "Learning online algorithms with distributional advice",
        "Online graph exploration with advice",
        "Putting the ‚Äúlearning\" into learning-augmented algorithms for frequency estimation",
        "Robustification of online graph exploration methods",
        "Learning-based support estimation in sublinear time",
        "Embeddings and labeling schemes for a",
        "On the evolution of random graphs",
        "A guide to heuristic-based path planning",
        "Learned data structures",
        "A systematic literature review of A* pathfinding",
        "Pebble guided optimal treasure hunt in anonymous graphs",
        "Bounded geometries, fractals, and low-distortion embeddings",
        "Augmenting online algorithms with ŒµùúÄ\\varepsilon-accurate predictions",
        "Learning-based frequency estimation algorithms",
        "Learning-based low-rank approximations",
        "Learning-augmented data stream algorithms",
        "Constructing competitive tours from local information",
        "A (slightly) improved approximation algorithm for metric tsp",
        "Treasure hunt with advice",
        "The case for learned index structures",
        "Learning the positions in countsketch",
        "Learning augmented binary search trees",
        "Competitive caching with machine learned advice",
        "Online graph exploration: New results on old and new algorithms",
        "A model for learned bloom filters and optimizing by sandwiching",
        "Algorithms with predictions",
        "A survey of a-star algorithm family for motion planning of autonomous vehicles",
        "Searching games with errors‚Äîfifty years of coping with liars",
        "Bi-directional and heuristic search in path problems",
        "Improving online algorithms via ml predictions",
        "A survey and classification of A* based best-first heuristic search algorithms",
        "Optimal robustness-consistency trade-offs for learning-augmented online algorithms",
        "Probabilistic computations: Toward a unified measure of complexity"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Learning-Based Algorithms for Graph Searching Problems, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
